name: StringScanner
comment: A class that scans through a string using string_scanner/dart-core.Patterns.

position.name: position
position.comment: The current position of the scanner in the string, in characters.

lastMatch.name: lastMatch
lastMatch.comment:
The data about the previous match made by the scanner.

If the last match failed, this will be null.

rest.name: rest
rest.comment: The portion of the string that hasn't yet been scanned.

constructors.comment:
Creates a new string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner that starts scanning from string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.StringScanner-.position.

string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.StringScanner-.position defaults to 0, the beginning of the string.

scan.name: scan
scan.comment:
If string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.scan.pattern matches at the current position of the string, scans forward until the end of the match.

Returns whether or not string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.scan.pattern matched.

expect.name: expect
expect.comment:
If string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.expect.pattern matches at the current position of the string, scans forward until the end of the match.

If string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.expect.pattern did not match, throws a dart-core.FormatException describing the position of the failure. string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.expect.name is used in this error as the expected name of the pattern being matched; if it's null, the pattern itself is used instead.

expectDone.name: expectDone
expectDone.comment: If the string has not been fully consumed, this throws a dart-core.FormatException.

matches.name: matches
matches.comment:
Returns whether or not string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.matches.pattern matches at the current position of the string.

This doesn't move the scan pointer forward.

error.name: error
error.comment:
Throws a dart-core.FormatException with string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.error.message as well as a detailed description of the location of the error in the string.

string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.error.match is the match information for the span of the string with which the error is associated. This should be a match returned by this scanner's string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.lastMatch property. By default, the error is associated with the last match.

If string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.error.position and/or string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.error.length are passed, they are used as the error span instead. If only string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.error.length is passed, string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.error.position defaults to the current position; if only string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.error.position is passed, string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.error.length defaults to 1.

It's an error to pass string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.error.match at the same time as string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.error.position or string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.error.length.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of string_scanner/string_scanner.StringScanner.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
